description.narrative:
Challenge 2.0 is aimed at providing mechanism for risk sharing capital supporting innovative business ideas in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Challenge 2.0 has a combined focus on economic growth, poverty reduction, CSR and innovation.
It is expected to support initiatives that directly contribute to job creation by assisting companies to grow and thus employ more people or gain higher value. Specifically the project aims at supporting innovative business ideas, products or services that lead to increased employment, increased competitiveness and sustainable socio-economic development in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

För att stimulera insatser inom den privata sektorn till utveckling och fattigdomsbekämpning. Denna Challenge Fond, för goda idéer, inbjuder företag att konkurrera om stöd på samma sätt som forskare söker medel från en forskningsstiftelse.

To encourage the private sectors’ contribution to development and poverty alleviation, Challenge Fund invites companies to compete for support for good ideas in the same way that researchers apply for funds from a research foundation.

description.narrative:
The project managed to organize 6 Calls of Proposals and it is noted that over the period, not only has the number of applications increased in general but more importantly the quality of proposals significantly improved. In total the project received 3 164 applications/projects. 234 projects underwent the second stage of evaluation followed by field visits by the Challenge team. Total number of signed contracts from all the calls is 212, while 33 grantees terminated contracts. The reason for terminating the contract on the side of beneficiaries is mainly attributed to economic and financial challenges businesses faced due to COVID 19 pandemic. In total, the project supported 179 beneficiaries.
In the financial terms, total amount of grant funds amounts to 3 746 067 EUR while the overall grant beneficiaries contribution to their respective project implementation is 6 805 258 EUR. The project supported investments in various projects in the amount of over 10, 5 million EUR. More specifically, the project:
1) Supported 179 innovative business ideas and/or inclusive businesses
2) Created 1 313 new jobs (822 permanent and 491 seasonal). Out of 1 313 new jobs, 619 women were employed while 709 youth. 4 863 working places were retains due to the project support.
3) Created income opportunities for 1 802 persons
4) Created new and innovative products, services or processes - 407
5) Created products, services or processes as added value in value chain - 57
Projects were implemented across the country representing a good geographic distribution including fair representation of what is considered as rural area. In fact the biggest share of implemented projects per sector are attributed to sector of agriculture (nearly 30%) followed by metal processing, wood processing and ICT.
When it comes to Start - ups they represent over 12 % of the overall grant beneficiaries while 88 % following the period of over two years remain active and are now considered as matured businesses. The project also aimed and measured success when it comes to gender 23% of businesses supported are owned by women while 21% have women for general managers.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
